bibl.title: Letter from E.C. Houle to Henry Rose Carter, May 9, 1923

div1.p: Houle writes that he has little information about trans-Pacific shipping from Mexican ports, but suggests where Carter can obtain an itinerary of all vessels.

div1.head: Letter from E.C. Houle to Henry Rose Carter, May 9, 1923
div1.opener:
T-3-23-10M.
Forma 2103
EN SU CONTESTACION REFIERASE A
IN REPLY PLEASE REFER TO
NO.
FERROCARRIL SUD-PACIFICO DE MEXICO
Empalme, Sonora, Mexico.
May 9, 1923.
Chief Surgeon.
H. R. Carter,
Asst. Surgeon General U.S.P.H.S.
2121 California St. N.W.
Washington, D. C.
My Dear Sir:
div1.p:
Answer to your letter of April 18th has been una-
voidably delayed by my absence on railroad construction in the
interior of Tepic and Jalisco.

I have made some effort to get the data requested,
with rather unsatisfactory results: The Pacific Mail and other
Steamship offices in Mazatlan had little information to offer
concerning other than their own lines, none of which were in-
terested in TransPacific shipping from Mexican ports.

There is no Japanese consular representive on the
West Coast of Mexico. The American Consuls advise that no
shipping whatever, passenger, freight or tramp, has cleared
from Guaymas or Mazatlan for TransPacific ports for several
years back.

Mr. Chapman, Consul at Mazatlan, suggests that you
will get most precise and complete data on all your questions
from files of replies of American Consular Officers to General
Instructions No. 886 of the Department of State. Instructions
dated January 2, 1923, concerning itinerary of all vessels, any-
where in the world.

Assuring you that I shall always be much pleased
to be of any slight assistance to you.
